intro: Pseuduvaria costata, commonly known as the serrated pseuduvaria, is a flowering plant native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Rubiaceae and is characterized by its slender, climbing stems and opposite, elliptical leaves with serrated edges. The plant produces small, white to pale yellow flowers that are clustered in umbels, followed by small, fleshy berries. It thrives in humid, shaded environments and is often found in lowland forests. Due to its ornamental value and ecological significance, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens.
